Himmelsbach | Improved UK let one slip away

Mark Stoops' job will now be bolstering the program's growing expectations.

Himmelsbach | Improved UK let one slip away

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 9:34 p.m. EST November 29, 2014

Video | Kentucky coach Mark Stoops on U of L loss

Kentucky's Mark Stoops reacts to a call during the game against Louisville. Nov. 29, 2014 By Matt Stone/The C-J(Photo: By Matt Stone/The C-J)

2 CONNECT 12 TWEETLINKEDIN 2 COMMENTEMAILMORE

Kentucky offensive coordinator Neal Brown walked out of the locker room and went outside to meet with reporters on this chilly, breezy November afternoon.

As he spoke, U of L coach Bobby Petrino's press conference was being broadcast on the Papa John's Cardinal Stadium scoreboard about 25 yards away. Petrino was smiling. He said something funny that those of us standing outside couldn't hear, but whatever it was made the people inside laugh, and it was so loud it even made it difficult to hear Brown.

The scene made for a fitting juxtaposition on this day. There was Petrino, towering over the Wildcats once more. It was not easy. Louisville 44, Kentucky 40 was closer than many predicted. But it was another U of L win, and for Kentucky, it was a sour way to end a season that had started with such promise.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky puts up fight but falls short in shootout loss at Louisville

"I never hid from the fact that it was important to win one of these games down the stretch," UK coach Mark Stoops said. "And we didn't get it done."

When the Wildcats surged to a 5-1 start that was an overtime loss at Florida away from being 6-0, there was an unmistakable sense that they had arrived ahead of schedule. After back-to-back 2-10 seasons, the impossible suddenly felt possible. Dreams suddenly felt like realities.

At the start of the year, the prospect of UK playing in the postseason would have elicited skepticism. Suddenly, it was less a question of whether the Wildcats would reach a bowl, and more a question of which one.

Sure, they would probably be underdogs along the way, but there was no way nearly being 6-0 would be followed by 0-6, was there? And then it happened.

GAME REWIND: Look back at the Cards' 44-40 win

AND: Quinton Baker decommits from UK after U of L game

But in retrospect, maybe expectations soared too quickly. Maybe it's best to view this season through a prism that shows a full body of work, not the order in which it was created.

This Kentucky football team, without question, grew this year. It became more confident. It showed that its talent level is rising. It got better. Now, though, the onus is on Stoops and his troops to ensure that the ascension continues.

"We definitely made progress, and the offseason starts tomorrow for us," said freshman running back Boom Williams, who gashed U of L's defense for 126 yards and two touchdowns on 18 carries. "We're gonna get to work."

That optimism will serve the Wildcats well as this winter turns to spring. They are young and talented, and reinforcements are on the way.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Tim Sullivan | Louisville QB Kyle Bolin shows poise under pressure

But we also shouldn't ignore the fact that Saturday's game was there for the Wildcats. They came off of their bye week and came into this stadium with a swagger that probably went too far. There were two pregame scuffles, and a large group of UK players even taunted Cardinals fans near an end zone before the opening kickoff.

Senior defensive end Bud Dupree said the Wildcats needed to show a certain intensity from the start. To have a chance, they needed to set the tone.

"Anytime you're in a great atmosphere, you need an edge," Dupree said. "So we came out before the game and got an edge."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Report: Kentucky offensive coordinator Neal Brown to take Troy head coaching job

And maybe it worked. The Wildcats zipped to a 13-0 lead, and then the bowl dreams reemerged. Even when the Cardinals surged in front and held the lead for most of the second half, UK punched back, getting a 14-yard Williams touchdown with 5:31 left to make it 40-37.

They just needed one more stop, but they could not get it. And so there was no choice but to turn the focus toward next year, toward continued improvement, toward the future rather than the present.

"The only thing they're gonna do is just keep going up," said Dupree, a senior. "We've been to the bottom, so just keep going up."

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach

Louisville coach Bobby Petrino talks about 44-40 Governor's Cup win over Kentucky.
